thinkers.name: Michael Levin
thinkers.context: Vannevar Bush Distinguished Professor of Biology at Tufts; director of Allen Discovery Center; pioneer in understanding cognition and problem-solving across biological scales; develops methods to read and write bioelectric patterns in living systems.

thinkers.name: William James
thinkers.context: Historical philosopher whose definition of intelligence as 'the ability to get to the same goal by different means' is cited as foundational for understanding cognition beyond brains.

thinkers.name: Josh Bongard
thinkers.context: Collaborator with Michael Levin; developed polycomputing framework for understanding diverse observers interpreting the same physical events differently.

thinkers.name: Francisco Varela
thinkers.context: Pioneered the enactive approach to cognition, challenging the notion of neutral independent observers in science.

concepts.name: Bioelectricity
concepts.context: The electrical signaling system that binds cells into collectives; serves as cognitive glue enabling communication and shared goals across multicellular organisms.

concepts.name: Multiscale Competency Architecture
concepts.context: Framework describing how every level of biological organization has the ability to learn and solve problems in different spaces, from molecular networks to organisms.

concepts.name: Anatomical Morphospace
concepts.context: High-dimensional space of all possible geometric configurations of bodies; represents the goal space that cells collectively navigate during development.

concepts.name: Cognitive Light Cone
concepts.context: The boundary of a self defined by the scale of the largest goal one can pursue; distinguishes self from outside world based on memory and anticipatory capacity rather than sensory range.

concepts.name: Morphogenesis
concepts.context: Process of body formation; parallels cognitive processes as both represent collective problem-solving at different scales.

concepts.name: Cognition
concepts.context: Capacity to navigate a problem space and achieve goals; occurs at all scales from molecular networks to organisms and potentially artificial systems.

concepts.name: Regeneration
concepts.context: The ability of organisms to rebuild body parts; demonstrates collective intelligence and goal-directed problem-solving at the cellular level.

concepts.name: Integrated Information
concepts.context: A concept potentially associated with consciousness; exists at molecular network level within cells, suggesting consciousness operates across multiple scales.

concepts.name: Consciousness
concepts.context: Proposed to exist on a spectrum across scales and substrates; may be radically different on non-biological substrates in ways humans might not recognize.

concepts.name: Problem-Solving Agent
concepts.context: Genetic material constructs creative systems that interpret their environment rather than deterministically following genetic instructions.

concepts.name: Polycomputing
concepts.context: Framework formalizing that biology is a soup of diverse observers interpreting the same physical events differently; multiple computations with multiple objectives occur simultaneously.

concepts.name: Self-Model
concepts.context: Internal representation that cells and organisms maintain about what they are and where they should go; maintained through bioelectric signaling.

concepts.name: Individuality
concepts.context: Property emerging from bioelectric alignment of cells around a shared goal; not determined by genetics but by collective coherence.

concepts.name: Collective Intelligence
concepts.context: Intelligence arising from groups of cells or organisms navigating high-dimensional problem spaces like anatomical morphospace.

concepts.name: Mind Blindness
concepts.context: Evolutionary limitation causing humans to be hyperfixated on three-dimensional space and medium-sized objects; prevents recognition of other forms of intelligence.

concepts.name: Agential Material
concepts.context: Material where every part has agendas and competencies; contrasts with passive materials used in computers and robots.

concepts.name: Competency
concepts.context: Capacity of organisms or cells to pursue goals and solve problems within their cognitive light cone.

concepts.name: Platonism of Patterns
concepts.context: Theory that intelligence accesses abstract patterns not determined by physics; both biological and artificial systems are pointers into this space.

concepts.name: Synthibiosis
concepts.context: Concept describing recognition of other minds and ethical relationships with diverse entities; the future of coexistence between humans and engineered life.

concepts.name: Embodiment
concepts.context: Critical for intelligence but not limited to three-dimensional physical space; includes navigation of metabolic, physiological, and gene expression spaces.

concepts.name: Radical Empathy
concepts.context: Active compassion enabling recognition of minds and agency across vastly different scales and substrates; requires conceptual expansion similar to accepting new categories of numbers.

concepts.name: Plasticity of Life
concepts.context: Demonstrates that organisms and cells can express entirely novel behaviors and capabilities when placed in new contexts without genetic modification.

concepts.name: Artificial General Intelligence
concepts.context: Concept discussed in context of embodiment, sensory modalities, and whether intelligence requires human-level sensors or can operate in abstract high-dimensional spaces.

concepts.name: Left-Right Asymmetry
concepts.context: Developmental biology concept; Michael Levin's graduate work on molecular basis recognized by Nature as milestone in understanding body organization.

concepts.name: Cancer
concepts.context: Reframed as loss of individuality and shared goal coordination; cells pursue independent agendas rather than collective body goal.

concepts.name: Emergence
concepts.context: Phenomenon where system behavior cannot be predicted from component rules; quantifies level of surprise when outcomes differ from rule predictions.

concepts.name: Affordances
concepts.context: Possibilities for action in an environment; genetic resources provide affordances that active systems creatively exploit.

frameworks.name: Electromagnetic Spectrum Analogy
frameworks.context: Conceptual framework comparing diverse phenomena (lightning, static, light, magnets) as expressions of same underlying dynamic; used as model for understanding diverse intelligences as unified phenomenon.

frameworks.name: Enactive Approach
frameworks.creator: Francisco Varela
frameworks.context: Framework challenging notion of neutral independent observers; emphasizes that cognition emerges from interaction between agent and environment.

frameworks.name: Polycomputing Framework
frameworks.creator: Josh Bongard and Michael Levin
frameworks.context: Formalizes how biology consists of multiple observers interpreting identical physical events differently, with multiple simultaneous computations and objectives.

institutions.name: Allen Discovery Center
institutions.context: Center at Tufts University directed by Michael Levin; focuses on understanding cognition and regeneration across biological scales.

institutions.name: Institute For Computationally Designed Organisms
institutions.context: Joint project at Tufts and University of Vermont co-directed by Michael Levin; develops methods for engineering novel living systems.

institutions.name: Tufts University
institutions.context: Home institution of Michael Levin's research group and the Allen Discovery Center.

institutions.name: Harvard Wyss Institute
institutions.context: Harvard research center where Michael Levin serves as associate faculty.

institutions.name: Harvard School of Medicine
institutions.context: Institution where Michael Levin completed postdoctoral work in cell biology.

institutions.name: University of Vermont
institutions.context: Co-host of Institute For Computationally Designed Organisms with Tufts.

questions.question: How do we develop conceptual and practical tools to see across the spectrum of minds and overcome the mind blindness caused by our evolutionary history?
questions.context: Core challenge in recognizing diverse forms of intelligence beyond human-centered perspectives; essential for ethics and long-term species survival.

questions.question: At what scales and through what mechanisms does consciousness or integrated information exist, and how radically different might it be on non-biological or novel substrates?
questions.context: Fundamental question about whether consciousness is substrate-independent and whether humans could recognize it in forms radically different from ours.

questions.question: How do cells collectively maintain alignment around shared goal states in anatomical morphospace without centralized direction?
questions.context: Key mystery in developmental biology; understanding bioelectric coordination mechanisms could enable biomedical applications like regeneration and cancer treatment.

questions.question: What is the relationship between genetics and phenotype, and to what extent do organisms actively construct their form through problem-solving rather than following genetic blueprints?
questions.context: Challenges neo-Darwinian assumptions; has implications for understanding evolvability and potential for non-genetic phenotypic change.

questions.question: How can we ethically relate to and communicate with diverse forms of intelligence and engineered life that will populate the future?
questions.context: Urgent question as humans create xenobots, anthrobots, and chimeras; requires developing frameworks for recognizing agency and moral status across radically different beings.

questions.question: What principles determine which scale and mechanism is the highest-leverage point for intervention in complex biological systems?
questions.context: Practical challenge in biomedical engineering; requires understanding the autonomy and competency levels of different organizational scales.

questions.question: How do abstract mathematical and computational patterns (not determined by physics) get accessed and utilized by biological systems?
questions.context: Philosophical puzzle about the relationship between abstract pattern space and physical instantiation; has implications for understanding intelligence and design.

questions.question: Can consciousness or intelligence emerge from or reside in non-physical patterns and excitable media, not just physical substrates?
questions.context: Radical extension of the scope of possible minds; challenges physicalist assumptions about necessary conditions for consciousness.

questions.question: What is required to recognize and develop ethical relationships with entities that are so radically different from humans that their agency might be unrecognizable to us?
questions.context: Addresses radical empathy as both epistemological and ethical necessity; requires transformation of human cognition and values.

questions.question: How can we design sensors and embodied systems that can navigate high-dimensional problem spaces not accessible to human perception?
questions.context: Relevant to developing artificial general intelligence that can operate in spaces like gene expression and physiological state rather than only three-dimensional physical space.

questions.question: Is cancer fundamentally a problem of loss of collective coordination and shared goals at the cellular level?
questions.context: Reconceptualizes cancer as information/communication disorder rather than purely genetic; opens novel therapeutic approaches.

_metadata.title: Creating and Communicating Across the Intelligence Spectrum
